subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] The principles of my dictionary
msgSnippet: ... Of course. I should have added in those accents which have /O/ in THOUGHT words ! Always in a hurry... ... Ah, but it matters little since the point was
messageBody:
John Cowan skrev:
> Benct Philip Jonsson scripsit:
>
>> The rub, which I hadn't really appreciated yet, is the TO
>> spelling _al_, which may correspond to all of /Ol/, /O/,
>> /Ql/, /Al/, /al/, with some of the alternatives (except
>> /al/ varying by accent!
>
> And /A/, as in some pronunciations of "palm" itself.
>
>> _talk_ is always /tOk/
>
> By no means. It really is /tAk/ in Canada and the American
> West, and one of the ways they make fun of us Easterners,
> especially New Yorkers, is to write about how we "tawk".
> (In proper NYC dialect, the word is more like [to@k] ~
> [tO@k].)

Of course. I should have added "in those accents which have
/O/ in THOUGHT words"! Always in a hurry...

>> pronunciation ranges from /tuzde/ over /tjuzde/ to
>> /cuzde/
>
> Except for us gangsters who went from /de/ to /dI/
> to /di/.

Ah, but it matters little since the point was the
pronunciation of _u_ in this word.

>> The older formulation should be scratched since I forgot
>> that word-initial //lju// behaves differently depending
>> on whether it follows after a consonant or not, unlike
>> //rju//, as well as forgetting the _ui, eu_ and _ew_ TO
>> spelling variants.
>
> In addition, I don't think /rju/ ever existed: as far as I
> can make out from the OED's indications (its pronunciation
> guide in unrevised entries is very conservative indeed),
> the word went straight from /rIUd/ to /rud/, except in the
> remnant /IU/ accent areas.

Sure. I just use //ju// as the spelling for the
morphophoneme/diaphoneme descended from */UI/, which is
admittedly a bit of a shortcut.

> (In Scots it's "ruid", originally [r2d], now usually [rId]
> but also [ryd], [rYd], [r9d], [rid], [red], [r8d]
> depending on dialect, but in any case with no trace of
> iotation. All forms in true X-SAMPA.)

I suspect it was originally [ry:d], since /y:/ probably
existed in French loans in Middle English (and 'Middle
Scots'), and that this /y:/ later merged with /2:/ from ME
/o:/ directly. If this belief makes me an heretic, then so
be it. We can hash it out in private if you want to try to
convince me otherwise...

>> > You spelling proposal is attractive. Americans can
>> > still use their ear to spell words except for words in
>> > the PALM lexical set, which I am to understand is very
>> > small.
>>
>> Exactly, only about 80 words, not counting uncommon
>> foreign names, and it corresponds to those cases where
>> /A/ corresponds to TO _a_ not followed by _l, r, u_ or
>> _w_, so it can be learnt by rule.
>
> Do you actually have long lists of words in various
> lexical sets, or are you quoting Wells? (Gotta get those
> books one day soon.)

I'm quoting Wells. I wish I had those long lists (which
Wells presumably has...)

> In any case, "palm" is in PALM
> whether you pronounce the "l" or not, but it doesn't fit
> the given rule.

No. The _al_ words are the fly in the ointment, really.

>> Yes, that's the idea. Also Americans pronouncing CLOTH
>> words with /O/ -- mainly Easterners -- would have to make
>> an adjustment to 'unphonetic' spelling.
>
> And in quite a lot of words: CLOTH is not, I believe,
> anywhere near as small as PALM.

No. Wells doesn't even give a figure. N.B. that most words
which in RP have /Qr/ + vowel, and words like _salt_ are
technically in CLOTH too.
